IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: The mission of NBME is to protect the health of the public through state of the art assessment of health professionals.
IRS990.MissionDesc: The mission of the NBME is to protect the health of the public through state of the art assessment of health professionals. While centered on assessment of physicians, this mission encompasses the spectrum of health professionals along the continuum of education, training, and practice and includes research in evaluation as well as development of assessment instruments.
IRS990.Desc: The United States Medical Licensing Examination (USMLE) is a three-step examination for medical licensure in the United States and is sponsored by the Federation of State Medical Boards (FSMB) and the NBME. The USMLE program supports medical licensing authorities in the United States through its leadership in the development, delivery, and continual improvement of high-quality assessments across the continuum of physicians' preparation for practice. It assesses a physician's ability to apply knowledge, concepts, and principles, and to demonstrate fundamental patient-centered skills, that are important in health and disease and that constitute the basis of safe and effective patient care.Note: The expenses reflected above do not include institutional indirect expenses.

ProgSrvcAccomActy2Grp.Desc: The Medical School and Student Services program provides assessment services to domestic and international medical schools, students, and residents. Assessments include the subject examination program, self-assessment services, and web-based examination programs and pilot projects. Subject exams measure achievement in the traditional basic and clinical science disciplines and are used to compare student performance with a national reference group. A series of web-based self-assessments are available to help students assess their readiness to take USMLE. Faculty services include item-writing workshops, and medical school liaison activities include the Advisory Committee for Medical School Programs.Note: The expenses reflected above do not include institutional indirect expenses.

ProgSrvcAccomActy3Grp.Desc: The Health Profession Services program provides comprehensive assessment, educational, consultative, and research services for healthcare organizations. During 2017, NBME's Health Profession Services worked with a variety of organizations to administer examinations for purposes of licensure, certification, maintenance of certification, evaluation of special competence, in-training, and self-assessment. These organizations included allied health professional associations, the national veterinary licensing board, members of the American Board of Medical Specialties, and medical societies. Examinations are administered worldwide, where applicable.Note: The expenses reflected above do not include institutional indirect expenses.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Part II-B, Line 1i - Other Activities Description
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: In response to proposed health care reform, NBME prepared a letter in support of preserving provisions of the Affordable Care Act that promote access to high-quality health care for all Americans and sent it to members of Congress.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Part V, Line 4: Intended uses of the endowment fund.
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE EDWARD J. STEMMLER, MD MEDICAL EDUCATION RESEARCH FUNDIn 1995, the NBME established the Edward J. Stemmler, MD Medical Education Research Fund. The Fund makes grants to support research in topics relevant to the mission of the NBME. The initial sum of $5,000,000 was invested and professionally managed with the goal of increasing the size of the Fund over time while providing total annual grants up to 5% of the trailing three-year average of the fund balance. As with all NBME invested funds, the Finance Committee monitors performance and recommends to the Executive Board any changes to the principal balance of the Fund.THE STRATEGIC EDUCATOR ENHANCEMENT FUND OF NBMEIn 2017, NBME established the Strategic Educator Enhancement Fund to provide opportunities of value to the community from which NBME obtains volunteers and other stakeholders. The initial amount of $20,000,000 was designated within NBMEs investments as a quasi-endowment fund. The maximum annual authorized disbursement from the quasi-endowment fund for 2017 through 2019 is an average of $600,000 per year. Beginning in 2020, the maximum annual disbursement in any year will be equal to 5% of the average of the trailing three-years ending balance of the investments.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Part X : FIN48 Footnote
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: NBME qualifies as a tax-exempt organization under the provisions of the Internal Revenue Code (IRC). Accordingly, there is no provision for income taxes reflected in the accompanying consolidated financial statements. However, NBME is subject to federal unrelated business income tax generated from debt-financed rental property.NBME had unrelated business taxable income of $48,000 for the year ended December 31, 2017 and incurred a loss of $29,000 for the year ended December 31, 2016 associated with the operation of debt-financed commercial rental property. Accordingly, NBME has a related net operating loss carryforward of $1,464,000 and $1,512,000 as of December 31, 2017 and 2016, respectively, expiring between December 31, 2028 and 2037. In addition, NBME has a deferred tax asset of $307,000 and $514,000 as of December 31, 2017 and 2016, respectively, which has been fully reserved due to the uncertainty of the realization of these losses. The deferred tax asset as of December 31, 2017 reflects a reduction of $193,000 associated with a lower income tax rate of 21% pursuant to the provisions of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017.NBME has no uncertain tax positions and there are no accruals for interest or penalties in the accompanying consolidated financial statements. Management believes that NBME is no longer subject to income tax examinations for years ended on or prior to December 31, 2013.(Amounts in the FIN 48 footnote for 2017 were slightly modified subsequent to issuance of audited financial statements.)

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Additional Supplemental Information
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Form 990, Schedule I, Part II, Line 1a - GrantsEach school is listed with the approved grant as follows:1. The University of Iowa Carver College of Medicine Proposal #1516-006, Validation of a Case Diagramming Tool to Assess Higher-Order Thinking Skills2. The Board of Regents of the University of Wisconsin System Proposal #1516-048, The Use of Epistemic Network Analysis to Evaluate Non Technical Skills Performance in Trauma Simulation Education3. Regents of the University of MinnesotaProposal #1617-973, Shared Mental Models and Learner Outcomes: Gap Filling of Validity Evidence to Support Time Variable Competency-Based AdvancementNote that the Harvard Medical School Proposal #1415-027 reimbursement of unused funds of $183 is not listed on the schedule in Part II.Contributions:NBME periodically makes contributions to organizations and/or community programs in order to assist in furthering the exempt purpose of those organizations. NBME also gives the Executive Board Chair and Treasurer the option of contributing their honoraria to their respective places of employment. The total amount of contributions made in 2017 was $115,450.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE EDWARD J. STEMMLER, MD MEDICAL EDUCATION RESEARCH FUND OF THE NATIONAL BOARD OF MEDICAL EXAMINERS (NBME)The purpose of the Stemmler Fund is to provide support for research or development of innovative evaluation methodology or techniques, with the potential to advance assessment in medical education or practice at eligible medical schools. Also see description of Stemmler Fund in Schedule D, Part V, Line 4 Intended Uses of Endowment Fund. The eligible applicants for Stemmler Fund grant awards are the medical schools accredited by the LCME or the AOA, and the number of Letters of Intent submitted by any eligible school is not limited. The Stemmler Fund Committee evaluates each application on the extent to which the proposed research is innovative or will advance assessment in medical education or practice, and will address an important problem or issue in medical education or practice. The Committee selects a subset of applications and invites them to submit full proposals. Peer reviewers with expertise in measurement, research design and methodology evaluate invited proposals on the relevance and significance of the proposal to the purpose and goals of the Stemmler Fund, the adequacy of the research design or methodology, and the qualifications of the principal investigator and project staff. The Stemmler Fund Committee reviews all proposals and peer reviews, also considering the budget, timetable, and other key project resources in each proposal, and selects awardees. Grant recipients are required to submit an interim and final report which includes a final project narrative and a final project fiscal report.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Part I, Line 1a: Relevant information in regards to selections on 1a.
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: First Class Travel and Travel for CompanionsNBME's Business Travel policy states that the most cost effective options available based on the traveler's requested itinerary should be made. First-class travel and travel for companions are not specifically authorized in the policy. In limited circumstances, certain NBME Officers and Key Employees may be permitted first-class travel if authorized by the President. First-class travel and companion travel for the President are included in the compensation package. The cost incurred for travel for companions is included in the employee's taxable earnings.Tax Indemnification and Gross-Up PaymentsNBME provides supplemental non-qualified retirement benefits to certain employees under the Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan (SERP) and Highly Compensated Employee Program (HCE) that are partially grossed-up for federal, state, and local income taxes. In 2017, 75% of the value of the SERP and HCE benefit provided to eligible employees was grossed-up. Therefore, the amount reflected on the employees W-2 includes taxes remitted by NBME for taxes on the employees behalf. See Schedule J, Part 1, line 4 for description of the SERP and the HCE.Social Club DuesNBME pays dues for membership to a private business club for its President.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Part III, Additional Information
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The amounts reflected on Schedule J, Column C Retirement and other deferred compensation include an estimate of the annual increase in the actuarial value of each employees benefit to be received at retirement under the NBMEs defined benefit plan for each employee. In addition, column C includes the amount contributed by NBME to an eligible employee's defined contribution plan, as well as earnings accrued under the Exective Deferred Compensation Plan. The amount in column C does not represent an actual cash payment to the employee during the year, but an estimate of the accrued benefit during the year to be received at a later date or at the time of retirement.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Client Note 1
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Client Note 1 - Note 1 - Form 990 Part I, line 6 - VolunteersNBME utilizes an extensive network of volunteers, many of whom are medical school faculty members and practicing physicians, to accomplish its mission. These volunteers contribute the highest levels of expertise in their profession to a range of activities including test development and governance. They receive a small honorarium in recognition of their service.Note 2 - Form 990 Part VI, line 1b - The President of NBME is an ex officio member of the NBME Executive Board.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part III, Line 4d: Other Program Services Description
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: OTHER PROGRAM SERVICES 4: The Post-Licensure Assessment System (PLAS) is a joint activity of the NBME and the Federation of State Medical Boards (FSMB). PLAS comprises two programs: the Special Purpose Examination (SPEX) Program and the Assessment Center Program (ACP). SPEX is a one-day, multiple-choice examination of current knowledge requisite for the general, undifferentiated practice of medicine and is intended to be used for reasons of endorsement or reciprocity of licensure. The ACP provides comprehensive objective and personalized assessments of physicians for whom there is a question regarding clinical competence. Together, the PLAS programs have assessed thousands of physicians over the past decade for reasons that range from endorsement of licensure to license reactivation after disciplinary action.Research and Discovery programs include the Center for Innovation, the Office of Research, and Product Discovery. This unit also oversees the Stemmler Medical Education Research Fund. The Center for Innovation serves as a portal to possible NBME futures by exploring concepts that could disrupt or otherwise affect the NBMEs future and by assimilating and communicating their implications. The Office of Research supports the NBMEs research enterprise by promoting a scholarly environment, coordinating the NBMEs research efforts across the organization, and ensuring that the NBMEs research portfolio is consistent with institutional priorities. The Product Discovery sub-unit oversees the generation of new ideas and their progression through concept development, prototyping, and business model development to create a portfolio of new products designed to meet the NBMEs diversification objectives. The Stemmler Medical Education Research Fund assists research in topics relevant to the mission of NBME and has supported 85 grant awards for a total of approximately $8 million since 1995. In addition to these defined programs of research and development, each program area and service unit is charged to carry on a program of research and development relevant to the work of the program or unit, for example, development of new item formats for USMLE, exploring relationships between prior measures and certifying exam performance for our clients and developing new testing methods for clients. These research and development activities result in the publication of dozens of research reports in scientific journals and presentations at scientific meetings each year.In aggregate, these programs deliver information vital for planning business strategy related to future assessment; and support conception and market testing of products ideas, and the research to investigate and sustain products.The Center for Advanced Assessment (CAA) is responsible for conducting research related to improving the quality and efficiency of NBME products, services, and procedures. It is also aimed at developing capabilities that allow the NBME to compete in new markets and offer new products. In addition to this work, the CAA provides non-routine technical support to other organizational divisions and subunits and conducts research to contribute to the field of measurement.NBME U is an evidence-based set of 28 online lessons designed to help health professions educators create reliable, high-quality assessments to evaluate student knowledge and skills. The latest version of NBME U, launched in 2016, was enhanced through development of a more robust learning platform, awarding 0.25 AMA PR Category I credits for physician learners, and a certificate of participation for other health professions educators.The North American Veterinary Licensing Examination (NAVLE), co-sponsored and co-owned by the International Council for Veterinary Assessment (ICVA) and the NBME, is a requirement for licensure to practice veterinary medicine in all licensing jurisdictions in North America. From 1998 until 2014, NAVLE development was governed by a series of contracts between the ICVA and the NBME. In February 2014, the ICVA entered into a collaborative relationship with the NBME with regard to the NAVLE. Under the collaboration, the NAVLE is overseen by the Collaboration for Veterinary Assessments (CVA) Governance Committee, comprising members appointed by the ICVA and the NBME. The purpose of the collaboration is to increase efficiency and facilitate NAVLE enhancements, drawing on the best of both organizations.The Health & Wellness Coach Certifying Examination is a collaborative program with the International Consortium of Health & Wellness Coaching. This new exam program is designed to assess competence in the field of health and wellness coaching. In 2017, more than 1,200 examinees took the pilot exam. OTHER PROGRAM SERVICES 5: NBME's International Programs unit provides students, graduate physicians, medical schools, and regulatory agencies with valid and reliable information regarding individual knowledge and overall curriculum effectiveness. The International Foundations of Medicine (IFOM) examinations represent a key component of NBME International Programs. The Clinical Science Examination (CSE) covers the core of clinical knowledge in medicine, surgery, pediatrics, obstetrics and gynecology, and psychiatry expected of students in the final year of undergraduate medical education. The Basic Science Examination (BSE) incorporates the common core of knowledge expected of students who have completed the preclinical curriculum and are about to begin study of clinical medicine. The NBME International Programs unit also offers a portfolio of consultative, faculty and institutional development, and assessment programs in the international undergraduate medical education, certification and licensure, and graduate medical education environments. Consultative services often include an on-site evaluation of the overall assessment capability for medical schools. The International Programs unit is also involved in various research projects related to the validity and reliability of various assessment tools.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 6: Explanation of Classes of Members or Shareholder
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The members of the NBME are responsible for electing its board of directors, the Executive Board, recommending policy for the organization proposed by the Executive Board, receiving reports on the annual budget, and approving amendments to the by-laws of the organization. The members of the NBME include its Executive Board, up to twenty-two representatives of the test committees, twenty-two representative members nominated by key constituent medical organizations, elected members-at-large, and honorary members. The members of the NBME meet annually. The officers and members of the Executive Board, elected by the NBME membership, meet four or five times a year.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 7a: How Members or Shareholders Elect Governing Body

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 11b: Form 990 Review Process
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Form 990 is reviewed by the NBME President, Chief Financial Officer, and General Counsel prior to filing the return with the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). The review is completed to ensure appropriate and complete disclosure. A copy of the Form 990 was provided to the NBME Executive Board and Audit Committee members prior to filing the return with the IRS.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 12c: Explanation of Monitoring and Enforcement of Conflicts
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The NBME has a written Conflict of Interest Policy for its members as well as a Fiduciary Duty and Conflict of Interest Statement for its Officers, Key Employees and Executive Board Members. These individuals are required to review and sign the applicable policy annually. Submission of completed statements by Officers, Key Employees, and Executive Board Members is enforced and annual disclosures of interests that could give rise to conflicts are monitored by the Secretary of the Board. Potential or real conflicts of interest are required to be reported to the Secretary of the Board or its President. If deemed appropriate, the party will be recused from the relevant proceedings.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 15b: Compensation Review and Approval Process for Officers and Key Employees
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Periodically, typically every three years, a Compensation Survey of Peer Organizations is conducted by an outside independent compensation consulting firm. The recommendations resulting from the survey are reviewed by NBME Human Resources and the Compensation Subcommittee of the NBME Executive Board. Officer employees and Key Employee compensation is reviewed and confirmed annually by the Compensation Subcommittee. Payments to non-employee officers are reviewed and approved by the Executive Board with interested officers recused. In setting CEO compensation, the Compensation Subcommittee uses the Compensation Survey of Peer Organizations and the results of the detailed annual CEO Evaluation of performance report from the CEO Evaluation Subcommittee of the Executive Board. The CEO compensation is set and approved by the Compensation Subcommittee of the Executive Board which then reports to the Executive Board that it has reviewed the relevant information and made a decision.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 19: Other Organization Documents Publicly Available
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: NBME governing documents, Conflict of Interest Policy, and financial statements are available upon request to the NBME Secretary of the Board.
